Author: randomdata
Content:
> You haven't shown any evidence that trades are better than going to college.

I'm not sure why I'd need to when I never made a value judgement towards either in the first place? Why would I care if one is better than the other? I'm not insecure about my educational choices enough to look for validation.

> What are you even arguing? I am lost.

Not arguing anything, just sharing basic economic theory. If you want to know more, they have college courses on the subject that cover the minutia that I could never accurately convey in a short comment here.

> "The trades are starting to gain appeal" Why? It's not in the numbers I see

Why? Because people are talking about it; frequently even, and not just Mike Rowe. People tend to ignore the things they have no feeling about, so we can see there is an interest level. Let's see those numbers though!

Author: thaumasiotes
Content:
Your problem is that you believe sensible plans are offered in the American market at all. Look at all the love people express for t-mobile's $30 / month plan. That's because it is leaps and bounds ahead of anything else you can get.

In China, I pay about US$15 every 3-4 months for a level of texting and voice talk that would easily cost $30 / month by itself in the US. (I don't have a data plan.)

I've tried going prepaid (also t-mobile) in the US. The economics worked out as long as I never expected to use my phone at all; if I expected anything, it was a money loss. And even while I expected nothing, I had to keep paying $10 / month so that all my paid credit wouldn't suddenly expire.

Author: freiervogel
Content:
Simple sequence would just be:\nbuild; run_tests

The syntax you quoted is doing a logical AND of two expressions. Expressions are any bit of script - including calls to executables (like the example).

It's a pity that PowerShell is Windows-only (Pash notwithstanding); its syntax is small, supports pithiness and verbosity equally well, and has an easy to understand flow once you're over the first learning hump.

> For example, the shuffle seemed more aimed at people who wanted something easy and light to clip on while exercising.

Speaking for myself, the shuffle is definitely aimed at my use case (I actually used a zen stone). I want to control my in-car music by hooking up a player with a purely tactile interface. Using my phone means every time I want to interfere with the player, I have to look at the screen... a huge step backwards in usability.

The zen stone had an adavantage that an ipod shuffle might or might not also have... no one ever broke into my car to steal it (although it was taken when they broke into my car to steal my backpack).

Author: sliverstorm
Content:
What relevance does Chernobyl have with modern nuclear power plants?

In line with this notion, I am reminded of automobiles. Automobiles of yesteryear were more dangerous and significantly more polluting (causing serious health problems for the residents of Los Angeles). But of course we clearly cannot point to a '57 Chevy with no seatbelts or catalytic converter and say, "Clearly cars are too dangerous and noxious to allow".

You may work hard for three years building your cupcake store only to end up with a business that's completely worthless because the overpriced-cupcake fad has been displaced by the bacon-filled-donut fad, and your recipes and brand name (which unfortunately has the word "cupcake" in it) are now worthless.

Author: hermanschaaf
Title: StackOverflow and Github Visualized As Cities
Content:
http://ekisto.sq.ro/

Ekisto is an interactive network visualization of three online communities: StackOverflow, Github and Friendfeed. A graph layout algorithm arranges users in 2D space based on their similarity. Cosine similarity is computed based on the users' network (Friendfeed), collaborate, watch, fork and follow relationships (Github), or based on the tags of posts contributed by users (StackOverflow). The height of each user represents the normalized value of the user's Pagerank (Github, Friendfeed) or their reputation points (StackOverflow).

Sharing this because I thought it's really awesome - published Dec 1 by Alex Dragulescu.

Author: dancapo
Content:
Wikipedia goes a long way, you know? You could do a lot worse than get it from there: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monad_%28functional_programming...

The term monad comes straight from Category Theory
Created: a branch of mathematics. There are some rules
column12:
and anything that obeys those rules is a monad.

From the point of view of programming languages
column13: any set of values/objects for which a particular set of functions exists is a monad. See wikipedia for what they are
column14:
exactly.

Monads exist on both dynamic and statically typed languages
column15: but it is more difficult to explain them on dynamic languages
column16:
where you don't have types to explain the properties.

So many things can be monads. For example
column18:
for it is easy to define "join" and "fmap" for them (one of the two possible ways of defining a monad):

* "join"
column20: means that if we have a collection of a collection (a list of lists of x
column21: a set of sets of y
column23: we can "flatten" it one level (that is
column24:
get a list of x or set of y);

* "fmap" means that
column25: if we have a function that changes the objects inside that collection
column26: we can create a function that changes the collection so that the objects inside it are modified. For example
column27: if we have a function from strings to numbers
column28:
we can create a function that converts a list of strings into a list of numbers.

A list comprehension in Python is an example of these rules put in practice
column29:
though when using "if" you are going beyond these rules.

There are other monads besides collection and the usefulness of monads is that they work like an interface or API that is shared by all monads.

Going to Python again
column31: y) for x in listA for y in listB]\n\nThe function f doesn't care that x and y came from listA and listB
column32: and if Python supported any kind of monad
column33:
then you could write something like this:

  monadC = [f(x
column34: y) for x in monadA for y in monadB]\n\nAnd that would work for any monad you passed. You would have abstracted away that you had lists
column35: making your code more generic and
column37:
more reusable and less repetitive.

To go with an example you use elsewhere
column38: you have a monad containing a file descriptor
column39: a read line function and a convert string to number function
column40:
then you'd get back a monad of a number:

  monadN = [int(readline(fd)) for fd in monadFD]\n
\nNote that monads don't define a way to extract that number from inside them
column42:
as you can continue to apply functions:

  monadVoid = [print(n) for n in monadN]\n
\nIf your original monad was a list of file descriptors
column43: you'd print a list of numbers
column44: one for each file. A Maybe monad (aka Option monad) would either contain a file descriptor or not
column45:
and you'd either print a number or not accordingly.

Another type of monad
column46: the Future monad (also known as Promise)
column47: executes the function they are given asynchronously. So the monad containing the file descriptor was a future monad
column48: then the code above would be executed and finish
column49:
but the number could be printed well afterward. I'll come back to this example at the end.

The usefulness or particular monads depends on the context
column50: but the ones I'm familiar with mostly help avoiding side effects in functional programming. If you don't avoid side effects
column51: you have no use for them. If you do
column52:
you'll inevitably come up with something equivalent to monads like the IO or State.

And the usefulness of the fact that they are monads comes from the fact that you can abstract away the specific type of monad they are
column54: coming back to our number-printing program
column55: let's say we are using a Future monad so that the number gets printed asynchronously
column56: and we wish to test the program. If we use the Future monad
column57: we'll probably have to sleep for a while and then see if the number was printed or not -- a test that may fail if the program takes too long to execute (say
column58:
the file is on a remote computer and has to be downloaded first).

One alternative is that we replace the Future monad with the Identity monad. The identity monad just holds a value
column59: so any operation on it is executed synchronously. We can test our program using the Identity monad
column60: so we do not have to way
column61: and run it in production using the Future monad
column62:
so our program runs asynchronously.

We can do that because they are both just monads."

Author: ChuckMcM
Content:
This is an important point, so let's be precise here.

The fact that a reactor is fueled by waste doesn't mean it doesn't create waste or have a waste-disposal aspect.

There is nothing in the physics of building nuclear reactors that prevents us from building a reactor that does not leave behind any waste that is either chemically reactive, or even modestly radioactive. No currently implemented reactor designs do that, but it is possible to create one that is both fueled by current reactor waste, and has no waste disposal aspect.

It is unclear if we could ever license such a reactor given the current climate.

Author: randomdata
Content:
> I need the same graph for people without college degrees.

You have me wondering: What need requires the same graph of those without degrees? All I ever claimed is that it is increasingly difficult to find a job with a college degree, which has been clearly shown. Even if we found out that 90% of non-college grads became unemployed in the same period, it wouldn't change anything I have said.

What would be very useful, however, is the same graph with people in the trades. My post did assume that the trade job market is improving over time, based on claims by Mike Rowe, and elsewhere. Unfortunately, I couldn't find any hard data to substantiate what they are claiming. You have to bear with me on that one. Regardless, the overall theory still holds true either way.

> 5% peak unemployment is pretty damned good.

Sure. I might even say it is great, all things considered. I'm not sure how that is relevant to the discussion though? We have been talking about general market behaviours related to supply and demand, not the exact market conditions on a given date.

Author: quesera
Content:
> RSS is not a growing market and I think only independent developers with small costs will end up alive in a few years. Feedly will either have to evolve and find a bigger market, or pare down the cost of hosting the majority of Google Reader expats. And that doesn't square well with taking investment.

Exactly right.

The rush to fill the Reader gap with a broad and compelling offering (high quality mobile and web apps) was a problem outside the scope of small developers, but the long term prospects for the market are below sustaining levels for larger, funded businesses.

I do hope Feedly can figure out a way, without making me dislike them en route. If not, I hope they offer a data export.

Author: timmm
Content:
> Risk is high almost always, with some exceptions.

The exception is taking on high risk with your startup.

I can imagine a pretty low risk scenario where you finish school, and start working in a relevant field programming. As you're making money and learning valuable skills you can spend your free time building your business. Unlimited runway and learning from your day job would increase your probability of being successful massively.

The billionaires and facebooks of the world are bad data points to model your future success by.

Author: BoostedGroup
Title: Watch K&N's Beautiful Ode to American Manufacturing
Content:
You may not know David Vespremi, but if you’ve spent any time at all around the aftermarket scene, you know his work. For the past decade, he’s worked as an automotive marketer with BoostedGroup, helping big companies tell their stories in compelling ways. One of those companies is K&N Filters.

Now, that partnership is coming to a close, and Vespremi wanted to say thank you. He took a small production team, spent some time in the K&N Filters manufacturing facility, and came out with a beautiful and moving tribute to both the company and American manufacturing.

Author: e12e
Content:
Hm, am I right in thinking that numbers are defined to be atoms in lisp. And also that there are limits to how one can use macros, in that you'd not be able to a) rename FIRST, as in (FIRST list) to 1 (or '1): (1 list) or ('1 list); and b) that you couldn't modify the syntax to "decompose"/parse a slice syntax like: (1:2 (list-of-lists)) (here 1:2 would mean for example first element of second sublist/cons) ?

Now, you could of course write an interpreter for such a language in lisp, but am I correct in assuming that there's no reasonable way to get a (standard'ish) lisp to compile an expression like (1:2 ...) to the equivalent caadr(?)-like expression?

I saw there's a library for clojure that adds "slice notation" -- but does so by adding a (slice x y list)-macro which of course is fine -- but it would seem that (x:y list) would give similar benefits to the cadr/cddr etc -- allowing selected subsets to be highly optimized, for example? (As well as offering concise syntax)

Author: stcredzero
Content:
Disappointing truth be told, Theodore Sturgeon's observation certainly applies to programmers talking. Mostly because the same ratios apply to the quality of programmers listening.

Most programmers are quick to pigeonhole you and what you say. Pay attention to their conclusions and note how careful they are(n't) about gathering enough info to arrive at those conclusions. Look for signs to see if they are skeptical of their own mental models.

This is how to pick who you should work with.

Author: gizmo686
Content:
Why can't you define a set monad? The first definition I can think of is making behave like Haskell's list monad?

That is to say that "xs ==> (\\x -> f x)" Would take every element in the set "xs", pass each of them into f, and union the results into a single set.

Author: refurb
Content:
Even in single payer systems, bankruptcy is often the result of medical issues. You have to remember that many conditions prevent you from working, so even if your medical bills are paid, you still can't afford your daily expense.

Interestingly, it turns out that research commissioned by the Canadian government shows that 15% of people over the age of 55 who declare bankruptcy cite a medical problem as the primary reason. Medical bankruptcies can, as I've been saying for a while, be driven by something other than the lack of free government provided medical care.

http://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2009/09/bankrupt..."
